qas.question: What was the original building that Chiswick House design was reinterpretation?
What is 1734 design is considered one of the finest example of Palladian architecture in England, built in Norfolk?
Who was inspired by the archite Earl when building Chiswick House?
What was a reinterpretation of Richard Boyles Chiswick House?
What was the Villa Capra purified up?
Whose dictate did the wings of farm houses follow?

context: At the forefront of the new school of design was the aristocratic "architect earl", <a0_0>Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington<a0_0/>; in <a1_0>1729<a1_0/>, he and <b4_0>William Kent<b4_0/>, designed Chiswick House. This House was a reinterpretation of <a2_0><b5_0>Palladio's Villa Capra<b5_0/><a2_0/>, but purified of <b6_0>16th century elements and ornament.<b6_0/> This severe lack of ornamentation was to be a feature of the <b7_0>Palladianism<b7_0/>. In 1734 William Kent and Lord Burlington designed one of England's finest examples of Palladian architecture with <a3_0>Holkham Hall<a3_0/> in Norfolk. The main block of this house followed Palladio's dictates quite closely, but <b8_0>Palladio's<b8_0/> low, often detached, wings of farm buildings were elevated in significance.
